awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Themally-Actuated Microfluidic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop a new technology to satisfy the need for reliable and inexpensive ultifunctional fluid handling and control in microfluidic devices. Building on the Phase I results, which demonstrated the fundamental concepts of thermal actuation of microfluidics, the goals of the Phase II program are to demonstrate, develop, and optimize thermal actuation techniques for all useful microfluidic fluid handling functions, and to demonstrate the ability to combine the various functions into an integrated device. To achieve these goals, methods will be developed for fabricating, operating, evaluating, and optimizing devices demonstrating each function of interest in a realistic application setting. The end result will be a complete microfluidic tool box that can be applied to supply fluid handling and control functions to a variety of customers for implementation in commercial microfluidic devices. 

The broader impacts of this research are in the areas of biomedical and biopharmaceutical research, and clinical diagnostics. Successful completion of this Phase II program would result in development of a set of thermally-actuated functional elements enabling a less complex and more cost-effective biomedical microfluidic device; the "lab-on-a-chip" system. The potential commercial value is significant. The increasing complexity of molecular diagnostic tests and the pressure to provide cost-effective, reliable, and repeatable point-of-care assays will continue to increase the demand for such systems. Societal impact of such a technology will include substantial cost reduction, more accurate and consistent results, and improved health care resulting from more rapid and specific treatment.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This SBIR Phase-II program was focused on developing a suite of thermally-actuated microfluidic functions to enable a low-cost (disposable), integrated, multi-functional microfluidic devices for biomedical applications. The concept originated with a valve actuated by using the thermoelectric (Peltier) effect to freeze a solid plug of fluid in a flow channel to stop the flow. The key advantage of thermal actuation is the ability to act across a separable interface. This makes it possible to build an actuation module containing all the actuation elements, and a separate fluid module containing little more than a set of flow channels. The actuation module never comes into contact with the fluids and so is reusable, while the fluid module can be simple and inexpensive enough to be discarded after use.

The commercial viability of this concept depends on being able to carry out a number of fluid handling functions with separable thermal actuation. The most problematic fluid handling function in many applications is a simple valve to start and stop flows. Other useful functions include fluid storage, pumping, mixing, filtration, and incubation. In the Phase-I program, we successfully demonstrated the operation of a separable thermally-actuated valve, demonstrated a thermally-actuated bi-stable valve (for fluid storage), and developed concepts for thermal actuation of a full set of fluid handling functions that could enable a multifunctional microfluidic device that can be operated solely by thermal actuation.

The goal of the Phase II program was to expand both the number of fluid handling functions, and their range of applicability. This was accomplished by building a microfluidics “toolbox” including a complete set of fluid handling functions, methods of fabricating the necessary hardware, and capabilities for working in various materials. The work was divided into two broad but somewhat overlapping categories; function development and manufacturing techniques. In function development, we worked with the complete set of fluid handling functions identified in the Phase I program, with the goal of demonstrating and/or enhancing the utility of each of these functions for biomedical applications. In manufacturing techniques, we looked at methods currently used to manufacture biomedical microfluidic chips, evaluated their implications for thermal actuation, and developed appropriate manufacturing processes suitable to thermal actuation. In addition, we developed manufacturing techniques to improve the performance of the thermal actuation module itself.
 
The work performed under this project produced a broad range of data, techniques, and innovations that will enable production of a commercially-viable thermally-actuated microfluidic system. The key developments included demonstration of all fluid-handling functions, as well as development of the infrastructure functions necessary to systems that can be reliably manufactured and easily incorporated into the workflow of a bioresearch laboratory. The key challenge encountered in the program was the phenomenon of supercooling. We developed several alternative strategies to overcome this challenge, and demonstrated these strategies in fully-functional devices. The broader impact of this work is that the technologies developed will enable development of a low-cost, disposable, rapid-response diagnostic system for detection and identification of infectious diseases in patient samples obtained at the point of care, which can lead to substantial reductions in patient-care costs, as well as reductions in unnecessary treatments driven by diagnostic uncertainties. The system is also useful for rapid, low-cost detection and identification of food-borne pathogens.


Last Modified: 01/13/2013
Modified by: Richard Welle
